[70]What? 
[71]The Romans had an expression they used to scare their children. 'Hannibal ad portas!' -- Hannibal is at the gates. Do you know who Hannibal was? Of course not. A pretty girl like you wouldn't know a thing. Colonel Getty, get some men up there and open that gate. 
[72]Make it quick.     I've got an attack to coordinate. 
[73]Do I know you? 
[74]You're the Postman, aren't you? 
[75]The restored United States. Do these people really believe that shit? Who are you really? 
[76]I was at the Battle of Georgetown. I watched the White House burn to the ground. Don't try to sell me on any restored U.S... 
[77]You're funny.    Now, what are the terms? 
[78]Appreciate your offer, Postman. Problem is, you're in no position to negotiate. These people made it through the bugs and the riots and the three year winter. But they're not going to survive you. 
[79]Law six, justice can be dictated. Kill him. And kill the restored United States with him. 
[80]Get her. 
[81]Colonel Getty! 
[82]What do you think, Lieutenant? 
[83]Yes... 
[84]Well, if it isn't our old friend the U.P.S. man. 
[85]Who the hell are you? 
[86]I want the camp struck at dawn. We're moving north. 
[87]You spelled tyranny wrong. 
[88]Nothing? Everything is here.    Am I the only one who sees that? Get out! 
[89]Give the people back their hope and their dreams won't be far behind. 
[90]What is it, Getty? 
[91]A military man, especially a commander, should keep a journal. After he's gone, it's the only real defense against the slander that arises. 
[92]No.  No. Not him. No. Children. I want a man and you bring me children! 
[93]Postage due... 
[94]You want a war? I'll give you a war. I was born for it! 
[95]No. Let it stand. All by itself. So it can remind them what it cost them. 
[96]You think you can ride? Then today's your lucky day. 
[97]He's out there somewhere. Watching. I can feel it. 
[98]You feel it too, don't you? Didn't have to end like this, Sheriff. He knew where I'd be if he wanted to face me like a man. Instead, he's hiding like a rabbit. So much for your Postman. 
[99]Fire! 
[100]Good lord, what do we have here? 
[101]A letter? 
[102]'Bethlehem. This letter is my testimony to the fact that there is no restored United States and there is no Postal Service.' Then who the hell have we been fighting...? 'My carriers are returning home. In exchange, I'm asking you to let them be. The Postman.' 
[103]He expects me to believe this? 
[104]Then I've won.     I've won. 
[105]You were supposed to kill him. 
[106]Why doesn't that surprise me? 
[107]Bring out the one we found yesterday. They can die together. 
[108]Wait a minute... wait a minute! 
[109]Hold your fire! You don't know each other? This will never be over. It'll go on except I'll be fighting a goddamn ghost. 
[110]No goddamnit. 
[111]No, I won't fight a ghost. Tabula rasa, gentlemen. A clean slate. I want all mail carriers hunted down. I want The Postman found. I want him dealt with. Colonel, organize the scouts. He rode west? 
[112]How many? 
[113]With guns? Are you sure? 
[114]Looks more like two hundred to me... 
[115]Only thing worse than a coward is one who can't count. Lieutenant, do yourself a favor. Die well in this battle. In my army a deserter's life is a brief and unpleasant one. 
[116]At last, someone with courage enough to bring the fight to me. 
[117]Reckoning, gentlemen. This is the day I've dreamed of. 
[118]They're an eager-looking bunch. Morale's a dangerous thing. Bring him up. I want this postman to see how the game is played. 
[119]God, I hope not. 
[120]My little shipping clerk. 
[121]Great men are made by other great men. Patton had Rommel. Grant had Lee. But I get you. 
[122]Are you trying to goad me into a fight? 
[123]Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way. 
[124]What? 
[125]You're not a Holnist. You're not a member of the clan. You don't have the right. 
[126]Where do I know you from? 
[127]Shakespeare. The one who didn't want to fight. 
[128]Law seven it is. This war is settled here! 
[129]I study people. I know your problem. Do you know why you can't fight? 
[130]You have nothing to fight for. You don't care about anything. You don't value anything. You don't believe in anything. That's what makes me better. 
[131]Would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing and bear-baiting. Oh, had I but followed the arts...
dialogues.ABBY:
[1]Would you like to dance? 
[2]All you got to do is hold on. 
[3]How tall are you? 
[4]Are you smart? 
[5]Just wondering. Did you ever have the bad mumps? 
[6]Have you ever had herpes or syphilis or anything like that? 
[7]So as far as you know, you have good semen? 
[8]I don't mean to be nosy. I'm only asking because I want you to make me pregnant. 
[9]This is my husband.    Michael. 
[10]We've been trying to have a baby for three years. We can't on account of Michael had the bad mumps when he was twelve. So we need a body father. We could ask a man here, but it could cause trouble. I've seen it happen. Things go okay until the woman starts to show. Then it can be bad. But you'll only be around once in awhile with the mail. 
[11]He hasn't said 'no'. 
[12]You'll be leaving tomorrow? 
[13]Everybody's up late writing letters for you to take. We're not supposed to waste candles like that, but they're so excited. 
[14]I don't have anybody to write to. 
[15]You're funny. Hardly anyone's funny around here. 
[16]Have you decided yet? 
[17]I don't want to. 
[18]It would be easier for me if you closed your eyes. 
[19]What are you looking at? 
[20]Another woman has pointed out to her what's going on. She can't hear what's being said, but she watches, concerned. 
[21]Michael! 
[22]watches from the flap of Bethlehem's tent.    The guard sees and shoves her back inside. 
[23]We can't stop now. They'll be coming after us. 
[24]Don't move. 
[25]You're right. 
[26]They killed Michael. 
[27]How sorry are you? 
[28]You got the mark of eight on you. 
[29]You're a liar.     I should've let you die. 
[30]Anything else? 
[31]Your legs are going to rot off if you don't try to walk. 
[32]You're lazy. 
[33]This is the last of it. 
[34]I'm going to check the pass. 
[35]Help! 
[36]I told you that's all there was. 
[37]I knew you could walk. 
[38]So?    What good is that now? 
[39]Look, there's something you'd better know. You're going to find out soon enough. I'm pregnant. It's Michael's baby. You're just the body father. 
[40]He tried with me almost every night. He couldn't do it. So he beat me. Said it was my fault. 
[41]The pass is clear. It's time to go. 
[42]Of course. 
[43]I set the fire. 
[44]You didn't think we'd stay here forever, did you? I'd appreciate if you'd walk with me long enough to find someplace safe for the baby. Then we can split up. You shaved. 
[45]It looks nice. 
[46]I've heard people talk. I've heard lots of names. Bliss. Hesperia. New Eden. Sheriff Briscoe says it's a fantasy. 
[47]But you're The Postman. 
[48]What are you? 
[49]No, tell us. 
[50]Yes? 
[51]I'm on the other side of town. 
[52]Ford's idea. 
[53]You're exhausted. You need rest. There's food in the trailer -- 
[54]You can't keep doing this. 
[55]Riding all the routes.   You're not saving anyone. 
[56]Ford thinks you're going to do something. 
[57]Ford doesn't know what it means to be a kid. He doesn't have your memories. None of them do. All they've got is the lousy world we gave them. And this is the only decent thing in it. 
[58]I knew it was something like that. 
[59]I remember... 
[60]Yes. 
[61]Where do you think he came from? 
[62]I'm hungry, Postman. 
[63]You never heard of a postman? 
[64]There used to be a postman for every street in America. They wore uniforms. And hats. Like this one... 
[65]My postman knew the name of every kid on my street. He knew our birthdays. He'd even find the baseballs you'd hit down the street. I can still see the smile on his face. The tip of his cap -- when he had a letter in his bag with my name on it. Mine always came just after school. You could set your watch by him. Unless you were waiting on something special -- like a present from somewhere far away or a letter from your sweetheart. Then it seemed like he'd never come. I used to think they could make time stand still. 
[66]I don't think we ever really understood what they meant to us until they were gone. Getting a letter made you feel like you were part of something bigger than yourself. No place was ever too far away for the postman. So nobody ever had to be alone. The postman was someone you could count on. Things just made more sense when they were around. That's the kind of world we used to have. A world a lot of us took for granted. And now we've got this one. And it makes me wonder -- what kind of world do I want my child to live in? I want my child to live in a world where hopes and dreams aren't just lies you tell yourself to get through another day. I want my child, and I want my friends -- I want all of us to live in a world where you still get your mail. 
[67]This is hard for me. Michael was the best man I ever knew. I never thought there'd be another man I could love the way I loved him. I don't know why I've been so blessed. And I've tried to find a way to be thankful, but I swear, if I lose you... 
[68]I don't know, but I believe in you. You have a gift, Postman.     I saw it back in Pine View. 
[69]You made Mrs. March feel like she could see again. You made Ford feel like he was part of the world. You give out hope like it was candy in your pocket. 
[70]When you come back, we'll be waiting here for you. So you can take us to St. Rose. 
[71]Your daddy wrote to tell you that he'll be here as soon as he can. And that he loves you very much. 
[72]Your daughter.     Her name is Hope.
dialogues.FORD:
[1]Cleaned and pressed, sir. 
[2]Yeah, I'm supposed to take you to Foster's. My name's Ford. Ford Lincoln Mercury. 
[3]Used to be John Stevens, but I changed it on account of I want to drive cars. 
[4]I live in that car. A 2003 Pontiac Sinatra. With a nine- banger and a Q-eight. 
[5]Were they fast? 
[6]A buck seventy-five on a strip. 
[7]A buck seventy-five? I thought maybe I could fix some of them up. It's nothing compared to what you do. 
[8]I knew you'd come here. 
[9]How do you get to be a postman, anyhow? 
[10]How could I do it? 
[11]Not anymore. That was kid's stuff. This is real. So, where's the right place? 
[12]Kinda like vampires, right? 
[13]What does? 
[14]I'll set them straight. 
[15]I've been lonely all my life. 
[16]Okay, then. 
[17]I want you to know I'd die to get a letter through. 
[18]I'll see you around. 
[19]These are going to Blue Jay. About twenty miles east. I thought I could take them. 
[20]I'm a postman. And I'm not hiding from anyone. I -- 
[21]The United States government. 
[22]I managed to save these. 
[23]I'm headed south. With the mail. 
[24]What kind should I be?... Haw! 
[25]More recruits? 
[26]Gather 'round, everybody. Got another letter here. Came in last night. 
[27]'Hello, all postal carriers.' 
[28]I'm here in Minneapolis with President Starkey, but my thoughts are with you. Remember, nothing worth doing can be done overnight. Keep your chins up and do your best not to get shot. Signed, The Postman. 
[29]Hold on now. There's a P.S... Anybody know what P.S. stands for? 
[30]Guess you want to talk about this? 
[31]I thought you were dead. 
[32]I lied. I told people you were in contact with me. 
[33]Because I didn't want it to end. 
[34]Sure. But you'll stay till he sends word? Right? 
[35]You'll stay 'til President Starkey sends word, right? Right? 
[36]Could you say a few words? 
[37]We bring all the mail here first. We sort it, group it and then it goes out. So far we got thirty routes. 
[38]Bethlehem is offering a 1000 pounds of gold to whoever brings you in. Dead or alive. 
[39]It's Red.   He's overdue. 
[40]What are you going to do? 
[41]You can't. 
[42]They'll kill you. 
[43]You can't help them! 
[44]No, this is all my doing.    I went against your orders. 
[45]The Holnists we killed. You told me to bury them. But I didn't. I sent Bethlehem the bodies. 
[46]Because Bethlehem has to know that we're not going to stop. 
[47]Bullshit. They're dying because of Bethlehem. They're dying because this is a shitty world. And if we're ever going to change it, then somebody might have to die. If I could make it be me down there I would. But I can't. 
[48]The rest are on the overdue list. 
[49]The President never wrote that letter. 
[50]Who's the other letter to? 
[51]What does it say? 
[52]What does it say? 
[53]It says you quit. What about the oath? 
[54]Then I'll take it. 
[55]If this is the end. If this is the last piece of mail that ever gets delivered. I'll take it. 
[56]I'm still a postman. You owe it to me... I owe it to me. 
[57]I'm a representative of the restored United States -- 
[58]Traitor... 
[59]Who are you? 
[60]Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury. 
[61]Law three.   Mercy is for the weak. 
[62]Law eight. There is only one penalty and that penalty is death. 
[63]Law eight... 
[64]... Live and let live.
dialogues.BRISCOE:
[1]I'm Sheriff Briscoe. Who the hell are you? 
[2]What does that mean in English? 
[3]Hand me your gun. 
[4]You got three seconds to get your ass outta here. 
[5]One! 
[6]Never heard of him. Two! 
[7]Three! 
[8]Johnny, why don't you run along. I need to speak to this man. 
[9]Johnny's real impressed with you. Whole town's real impressed with you. 
[10]Smarter than you look. 
[11]You can clear out. Or I can throw you out. Either way suits me fine. 
[12]You're not authorized by shit. You're nothing but a drifter who found a bag of mail. And I want you out of my town. 
[13]These people don't need dreams, Mr. Postman. They need something real. They need help with the goddamn Holnists. Are you going to bring them that? Didn't think so. All you cost us so far is a few bowls of soup and maybe later a few broken hearts. I aim to keep it that way. You can stay till morning. Then I don't ever want to see you again. 
[14]I'm your escort out of town. 
[15]You got a helluva nerve, whoever you are. 
[16]She and Michael are working the north meadow this morning. 
[17]Well, you're on your own. 
[18]Hey! Are you really who you say you are? 
[19]God damn it! 
[20]Holnists, Johnny. You gotta stay out of sight. 
[21]You stay out of this, or I'll lock you up myself damnit. 
[22]General Bethlehem. We're gathering the tribute, sir. Can I take your wagons? 
[23]You didn't have to -- 
[24]Aw, Michael... 
[25]Man came through here. With mail. Said he was a postman. Said the government had been restored back east. 
[26]East. 
[27]Take that thing off, Johnny.    You want to die, too? 
[28]Don't be a damn fool. 
[29]Phil, this better not be another of your U.F.O.'s. 
[30]I'll be damned. 
[31]I'd have shot you myself. 
[32]Things are getting better. Getting better all the time. I don't know who you are, but I do know I was wrong about you. 
[33]It's from my sister. I thought she was dead. 
[34]Ride, Postman! Ride! You hear me? I said ride!
dialogues.IDAHO:
[1]All men between 15 and 50 and of suitable ethnic foundation are required to show themselves now. 
[2]Sir? 
[3]You were required to show yourself. 
[4]Take the mule. 
[5]Let's move it.     Everybody up and at 'em. 
[6]All right, girls. We're gonna run. Twenty miles. With packs. You got three hours. Everybody makes it. Or nobody eats. 
[7]Eat up!    You got meat tonight. 
[8]Why don't you tell Shakespeare what kind of meat that is. 
[9]A godawful animal. The sterile offspring of a horse and a donkey. Can you imagine that?! There's no room in this new world for a bastard like that. 
[10]Uh uh. Any man last in line ain't hungry enough. You show up last, you don't eat! 
[11]You thinking of challenging for leadership of the clan? 
[12]You see Colonel Getty? Always following the General? He's the only man who ever challenged. Fight lasted six seconds, but the General didn't kill him. He cut off his tongue and he cut off his balls and old Getty's been following him like a dog ever since. 
[13]The General don't see it, but I say you got some nigger in you. 
[14]The General would like a word with you, Shakespeare. 
[15]And the book, sir? 
[16]One of you dogs has earned himself a treat. Over there. 
[17]Those men hunted themselves a lion this morning. Must've been a zoo around here before the war. Anyhow, they shot him and he crawled into that thicket. A third man went in after him. We don't know if he's dead or alive. I need a volunteer. Someone's gotta go in and get our boy out. 
[18]I guess size ain't a measure of courage, is it? Shakespeare! 
[19]Maybe you'll find your St. Rose up there. 
[20]What are you waiting for, Christmas? 
[21]Hurry up! You still got a lion to bag! 
[22]Good, boy.   Get him. 
[23]Finish it. 
[24]Tracking. He sees a dribble of fresh blood.   He touches it with his fingers and smiles. He cocks his head at MOVEMENT to his left. Smiling, hefting his pistol, Idaho moves in. More SHUFFLING.   Just ahead. He's got him now. 
[25]You want your St. Rose?

[1]What do you got in there?

[3]Maybe he fell asleep. 
[4]We're rich! 
[5]Hi.

[7]Wow! 
[8]We traded them for a woman.

[10]I'll die before I'm last in line again.

[18]I'll go.

[21]I got him!   Over --

[18]Yes, sir...
dialogues.PONYTAIL:
[1]Carrier 18. U.S. Postal Service. Got any mail? 
[2]Ain't you heard of The Postman? 
[3]He's only the greatest man who ever lived. He crossed the wasteland, shook his fist at the enemy and spit in the eye of General Bethlehem himself. He's back east with President Starkey right now. 
[4]Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury. He's in direct contact with the restored congress. 
[5]Do you have mail, or don't you? 
[6]Thirty-two.    As of midnight. 
[7]His letters are always kind of short. 
[8]I found him!   I found him! 
[9]Route twenty-two. I'm already an hour late. 
[10]What rule? 
[11]But they're waiting on their mail down there. 
[12]You're hurting him. 
[13]We know their names. The little one's my brother. His name is Billy. 
[14]What Ford did was wrong. But it doesn't change anything for any of us. Does it? 
[15]No. 
[16]President lives in a white house. That guy's place is gray. 
[17]Ready for duty, sir. 
[18]Talk to the people. Gather who's willing. Tell them it's important. Tell them we can make a difference.
dialogues.CHUBBY:
[1]You got another letter? 
[2]Did you get a letter or didn't you? 
[3]Holy shit... 
[4]I seen him once when I lived in Benning. It's The Postman! 
[5]Boy, he's smart. 
[6]Boy, he's smart.

dialogues.LEAD BANDIT:
[1]Portland's under twenty feet of water. 
[2]You mouthin' me?

dialogues.OLD GEORGE:
[1]Seventy-five, sir. 
[2]Nope. Can't walk too good, either. 
[3]I know stuff. 
[4]1970. A girl with eyes as big as saucers did me in a little town called Saigon. 
[5]Not a soul in seven years of trying. But I will. 
[6]Go ahead. Take a look. Want some? 
[7]I was an aerospace engineer. I helped design the Galileo space station. I dream it's orbiting Earth forever. With a dozen human skeletons all grinning at each other. Laughing at us down here. 
[8]Steady, boys, steady. 
[9]Get on with it, you floppy-eared sonuvabitch!
dialogues.LUKE:
[1]Sir? It'd be an honor if I could shake your hand.

[4]General Bethlehem said... ... You should be on your knees when I do it. 
[5]The general is a great man. 
[6]It's true, sir. I was there. He disbanded the carriers and rode west. 
[7]I couldn't get close enough. This one's his second in command. 
[8]Four.    No more tattoos.
dialogues.MAYOR:

[3]What the hell are you doing?! Open the gates!

dialogues.MICHAEL:
[1]What do you say, mister?     You'd be doing us a favor.
